start.title:
Ecothreads
How businesses use systems of Linear Functions
start.description: Can you help Mei make her Ecothreads T-shirt business a success? In this STEAMQuest, you will explore how businesses use linear functions to analyze costs, revenue, and break-even points.

introduction.mei_thinking: My T-shirt designs are getting so much love online. But can I turn this into a real business? I need to ask Aunt Lily...

aunt-lilys-office.aunt_lily_greeting: Mei! It's great to see you. What's this business idea you mentioned?
aunt-lilys-office.mei_explanation: Well, you know I've been selling my eco-friendly T-shirt designs online. I'm thinking of turning it into a full-fledged business, but I'm not sure if it's worth the investment.
aunt-lilys-office.aunt_lily_offer: That's exciting! I'd love to help. Let's break it down using some business math. We can make some linear functions to model your costs and revenue.
aunt-lilys-office.mei_question: Linear functions? How does that apply to T-shirts?
aunt-lilys-office.aunt_lily_explanation:
You'd be surprised!
Let's start with the basics. In any business, you have costs and revenue.

understanding-cost-functions.aunt_lily_formula: Let's take a look at a formula for cost
understanding-cost-functions.aunt_lily_explanation: You'll have two types of costs: fixed costs, which don't change no matter how many shirts you sell, and variable costs, which increase with each shirt made.
understanding-cost-functions.aunt_lily_formula_explanation: Now, let's say your fixed costs for equipment and setup are $1000, and each shirt costs $10 to make.
understanding-cost-functions.mei_understanding: Oh, I get it! So the $1000 stays the same, but the total cost goes up by $10 for each T-shirt?
understanding-cost-functions.aunt_lily_confirm: Exactly! This is a linear function, where x is the input (number of shirts) and C(x) is the output (total cost). Let's play around with the numbers.
understanding-cost-functions.aunt_lily_example: Let's say your fixed costs are $1000, and it costs $10 to make a T-shirt. What is the cost of making 25 T-shirts?
understanding-cost-functions.mei_answer: Ok, I still need to pay $1250.
understanding-cost-functions.aunt_lily_question: And what if you sell 100 shirts?
understanding-cost-functions.mei_calculation: If the fixed cost is $1000 and the per-unit cost is $10, then for 100 T-shirts... the total cost would be $2000!
understanding-cost-functions.aunt_lily_praise: Perfect! You're getting the hang of it. Now, let's talk about the fun part: making money!

cost_function_calculator_interaction.title: Cost Function Calculator
cost_function_calculator_interaction.aria_label: Graph showing the cost function, displaying the relationship between cost and the number of T-shirts produced.

labels.x_units_y_dollars_label: where x is the number of units and C(x) is the total amount in dollars

cost_function_calculator_interaction.heading: Cost Function Calculator
cost_function_calculator_interaction.instructions:
Hint: Follow these steps:

  1. Set the Fixed Costs slider to $1000
  2. Set the Per-Unit Cost slider to $10
  3. The total cost will be: Fixed Costs + (Per-Unit Cost × Number of T-shirts)
  4. Remember: You're making 25 T-shirts, so don't forget to include BOTH the one-time fixed cost AND the cost for each shirt!
cost_function_calculator_interaction.about:
This calculator helps you understand business costs! Your total cost has two parts:

  • 1.
    Fixed costs (F): What you pay even if you make zero items
  • 2.
    Per-unit costs (p): Cost to make each additional item

The cost function is written as: C(x) = F + px, where:

  • •
    C(x) is your total cost in dollars
  • •
    F is fixed costs
  • •
    p is per-unit cost
  • •
    x is number of items

The graph shows how total cost changes as you make more items. Adjust the sliders to see how different fixed and per-unit costs affect your total costs!

cost_function_calculator_equation.title: Cost Formula
cost_function_calculator_equation.formula_equation: total costs = variable costs + fixed costs
cost_function_calculator_equation.cost_types_explanation:
total costs = variable costs + fixed costs

You'll have two types of cost:

Fixed Costs

Don't change no matter how many shirts you each shirt you make

Variable Costs

Increase with each shirt made
cost_function_calculator_equation.detailed_cost_function:
total costs = variable costs + fixed costs

\[{\color{#CC3700}{C(x)}} = {\color{#4168E1}10x} + {\color{#1C6F1A}1000}\]
x is the number of T-shirts sold
10x is the variable cost ($10 per T-Shirt)
1000 is the fixed cost ($1000)
C(x) is the cost of x T-shirts
cost_function_calculator_equation.function_notation_info:
The expression C(x) is function notation - it's not C multiplied by x . Think of it as one symbol meaning "the cost function."

In C(x) = 10x + 1000:
  • •x represents the number of shirts (the quantity), not dollars
  • •The fixed cost (1000) stays the same no matter how many shirts you make
  • •We could have named this function anything (like T(x) or F(x)) - using C just helps us remember it's cost

Remember: To find the total cost for any number of shirts, replace x with that number and calculate 10x + 1000.

understanding-revenue-functions.aunt_lily_explanation: Now, let’s look at your revenue function. If you sell each T-shirt for $25, it looks like this:
understanding-revenue-functions.mei_revenue_understanding: Right, it starts at zero and goes up by $25 for each T-shirt sold.
understanding-revenue-functions.aunt_lily_revenue_description: Exactly! Let's explore how selling price affects total revenue when selling a specific number of T-shirts.
understanding-revenue-functions.aunt_lily_revenue_example: Set the selling price to $25. How much revenue would you generate from selling 100 T-shirts?
understanding-revenue-functions.mei_revenue_calculation: Okay, so if I set the price to $25 and sell 100 T-shirts, my revenue would be... $2500! That'd be great!
understanding-revenue-functions.aunt_lily_praise: Perfect! You're getting the hang of it. Now, let's talk about the fun part: making money!

revenue_function_generator_interaction.aria_label: Graph representing the revenue function, showing how revenue changes based on the number of T shirts sold.

labels.x_units_y_dollars_label: where x is the number of units and c is the total amount in dollars

revenue_function_generator_interaction.heading: Revenue function generator
revenue_function_generator_interaction.about:
Getting Started

  • Set your selling price for each item using the slider
  • Enter the number of T-shirts you want to produce
  • View your total revenue and revenue function below
  • The graph will update to show how your revenue changes
revenue_function_generator_interaction.instructions:
This calculator helps you understand how much money your business makes! Your total revenue has one main part:

Price per unit (p): The selling price for each item you sell

The revenue function is written as: R(x) = px, where:

  • R(x) is your total revenue in dollars
  • p is selling price per unit
  • x is number of items

The graph shows how your total revenue changes as you sell more items. The line goes up because each item you sell adds to your revenue. Try different selling prices to see how they affect your total revenue!

revenue_function_calculator_equation.title: Revenue Formula
revenue_function_calculator_equation.data:
In a revenue model, we use the formula:
\[{\color{#CC3700}R(x)} = {\color{#4168E1}25x}\]
x is the number of T-shirts sold.
25 is the price of each T-shirt.
R(x) is the total revenue from selling x T-shirts.
revenue_function_calculator_equation.function_notation_info:
Function Notation Made Simple!

When we write R(x) = 25x, remember:
  • •R(x) is not multiplication! It means "revenue you get when you sell x shirts"
  • •The x can be any number (that's what makes it a function!)
  • •When we write 25x, we mean multiply 25 by x

Try it yourself:
  • •If x = 2 shirts: R(2) = 25 × 2 = $50
  • •If x = 10 shirts: R(10) = 25 × 10 = $250

Pro Tip: Think of R(x) as a machine - put in number of shirts, get back total money!

Remember: In R(x) = 25x
  • •Input: number of shirts (x)
  • •Output: money you make (R(x))

break-even-analyzer.aunt_lily_break_even: Right, but we need to think about costs. So let's find your break-even point.
break-even-analyzer.aunt_lily_equation: That's where solving equations comes in. Actually, we can set the two functions equal to each other!
break-even-analyzer.mei_equation_question: That's it? I can just set them equal and solve for x?
break-even-analyzer.aunt_lily_equation_explanation: Yes, because here you want to know when the two functions are equal. Kind of cool! Let's play with this.
break-even-analyzer.aunt_lily_past_context: We've looked at costs and revenue separately. Now let's see how they interact to determine profitability
break-even-analyzer.aunt_lily_description: Our T-shirt business has fixed costs of $1000 and variable costs of $10 per shirt. We're selling each shirt for $25.
break-even-analyzer.aunt_lily_interactive_question:
Now you can see how changing your costs or prices affects when you'll start making a profit.

How many T-shirts do you need to sell to break even?
break-even-analyzer.mei_gratitude: Thank you so much, Aunt Lily. I want to create a sustainable business that's good for both the planet and make some money! Time to make this dream a reality.

break_even_analysis_interaction.title: Break even analysis
break_even_analysis_interaction.aria_label: Break-even analysis graph showing the relationship between cost and revenue with the break-even point indicated where total cost equals total revenue.
break_even_analysis_interaction.heading: Break even analysis
break_even_analysis_interaction.instructions_heading: How to Use This Analysis Tool
break_even_analysis_interaction.about:
Start by understanding what each slider does:

  • •
    Equipment Cost:This is your fixed cost (where the cost line starts on the y-axis)
  • •
    Material Cost:This is part of your variable cost (affects the steepness of the cost line)
  • •
    Selling Price:This determines how quickly your revenue grows (steepness of revenue line)

Try changing just one slider at a time to understand how each affects the graph!
break_even_analysis_interaction.instructions:
• •
    First set your Equipment Cost - notice how this moves the starting point of the cost line
  • •
    Then set Material Cost - watch how this changes the angle of the cost line
  • •
    Finally, set Selling Price - see how this changes the angle of the revenue line
  • •
    The break-even point is where the red cost line meets the green revenue line
  • •
    Remember: You're looking for the point where Total Cost = Total Revenue. At this point, you're neither making nor losing money.

revenue.definition: Revenue is the total amount of money earned from selling goods or services.

linear_functions.definition: Linear Functions are mathematical relationships as a straight line on a graph.

Linear_functions.definition: Linear Functions are mathematical relationships as a straight line on a graph.

break_even_point.definition: Break-even point is the magic number where you've made exactly enough money to cover all your costs - not losing money anymore, but not making extra money yet either.

profit.definition: Profit is the extra money a business makes after paying all its costs.

common.x_units_y_dollars_label: Where x is the number of units and c is the total amount in dollars
common.invalid_input_submitted: One or more inputs are invalid!
